post: Do you check for bedbugs when you get to a new hotel?

comment.body: I check every hotel and air bnb. I just lift the sheets and use a flashlight. They can be very expensive and hard to get rid of, so I’d prefer to avoid bringing them back if at all possible.
Doesn’t matter how nice a place is. First thing I do I lift all the bedding and check for those little fuckers.

Check mattress on arrival and **also check your sheets on departure.**  If your hotel has bugs they will probably show spots on the sheets after a night or two.  That way you can take precautions to avoid bringing them home.

Also, put your luggage on a hard surface (some people even will store it in the bathtub, but my preference is the luggage rack, separated from the wall a little bit).  Never store it on the floor or next to the bed.  The little buggers will crawl in and then you take them home.

Omg yes I check every time. Hotel, Airbnb, glamping, doesn’t matter. I check. Every. Time. A bed bug run-in at a hotel in 2015 has me traumatized for life. I don’t use a hairdryer or iron, I use a flashlight and lift every mattress and check the headboards and behind the night tables and headboard if you can see back there.

Yep, got to an airbnb spent a few hours on the couch before going to bed. Went to lay in the bed but noticed some things crawling on the side of the bed... full blown bed bugs on a highly rated property. The owner said I brought them in... I never touched the bed

Yes absolutely. We got bed bugs a few years ago and it took six months of steam cleaning our couch and bed (mattress and frame - since the frame is fabric) consistently (daily then weekly) to finally get rid of them. Never again. I check the mattress, and everything gets bagged and washed/dried immediately upon returning home.

Bedbugs fluoresce under UV light.  I put my stuff in the tub, turn off all the lights, and check bedding and upholstery.
Light is small and was $15 at AutoZone.
Hell yes

I travel 90 days a year, have for years, and have both never checked and also never had a problem.

I'm sure it hits every hotel, and most hotels see this issue about once or twice a year.
Is anyone else feeling itchy ever since reading this post?
Lift all the sheets and check any crevices on the mattress for bugs or black specs.

Never did. Have never thought about it and most of the time I was too tired.

I have eradicated bed bugs from my apartment twice. Yes I know about them.

After the Reddit algorithm hooked me here, I started checked every hotel room. 

Suitcase and bag outside in the hall, I walk in with phone, and inspect the corners of the mattress. If all is good, quick check of the dresser and sofa (if applicable) and then bring stuff inside.
I always check now after an incident where I woke up in the middle of the night from being bit by something at a hotel, and ended up finding bed bugs in the bed. I’d rather know.
Never checked. Never any issues.
Never not once lol. And never noticed any issues.

Yep. Check the bed, furniture, carpet, rugs, anything fabric/upholstered with a flashlight before I open my suitcase or even sit down. My dad brought them home once, it costs a pretty penny to get rid of those little bastards.

I had a horrible experience with bedbugs once: hundreds of bites all over my body, had to throw away my suitcase. 

But I’ve never checked for them before or since.

Yes I always check the room before I bring anything in or put any items down. It's not just bedbugs, it's roaches and fleas as well. I also look up the address on the bedbug registry website and check Yelp and Google reviews before I book.
Nope. I’ve stayed in a thousand hotel rooms and only got bedbugs once from the nastiest hostel in Rome lol
Yes I always check. I also clean the TV remote with disinfectant wipes.

I’ve never checked for them in the soft furnishings, but I check the Bedbug Registry on line before booking anywhere.  After watching a video of someone checking a bed with an iron I’ve thought I might try  it.

My spouse used to work at a hotel, a NICE hotel at that. He's absolutely religious about checking after seeing the nightmare bedbugs can cause, and they can pop up in the nicest, cleanest hotels. He's also 100% obsessed with never allowing our luggage to be put anywhere but on a shelf, table, desk, or counter. Never do our bags or clothing get put on beds or floors. Bed bugs can't really climb smooth surfaces, so most tables and counters are pretty safe. 

So, the answer is a hard yes, we check. That also includes checking plane seats and train beds and seats when possible.

Bedbugs are horrible. They really mess with your mental health. 

I had one long bout with them (our building in NYC had them.) Ruined my relationship, my mental state, my finances. After months of fumigating, got rid of them, then moved out and bought everything new. 

Then, 3 years later, I was backpacking for months through Europe. I arrived exhausted, late at night, to a hostal in Bilbao.  The only place with vacancy. I noticed one climbing up a wall, killed it, fresh blood. I was horrified. I saw another on a different wall. I was horrified, but had nowhere else to go. So I did the only sensible thing. 

I carefully hung my bag off of a wall (nothing had come in contact yet. Basically said to myself “I have nowhere to go at this hour, I need to sleep. I will offer myself to these for tonight, then trash all of these clothes and change into safe ones.”

You want to avoid them, so yes, I check hotel rooms…. They really screw with you.
Always! I've never found any, but always check!

I have a friend whose husband traveled all over the world. His suitcase didn't leave the laundry room. His clothes went directly to the washer or cleaners after each trip. His suitcase wasn't allowed out of the laundry room.

Yes. Every. Single. Time. It doesn't matter where I stay or what type of accommodation. I have found bed bugs at an upscale resort on Kauai that I never would've expected along with in first class seats on an airplane.

The minute I walk in. I used to do a lot of traveling for work and woke up at home one morning to discover them. I spoke to the pest control guy about what he does when he travels. Besides the usual of putting the luggage in the tub, never on the floor or bed, and inspecting. One thing he does is always ask when checking in what their policy is when bed bugs are reported. This lets them know you’ll be doing a thorough check and will likely not check you into a room or one close by that was previously reported as having them.
DIdn't used to, but... Got 'em once, and I'm pretty sure I know the hotel they came from.

I have been a business traveler for 24 years and never once have I looked for bed bugs, used a UV light or sprayed disinfectant on anything. Short of leaving the hotel if you ask for another room more than likely the same person that cleaned your room cleaned the one they want to move you to.
Always. It doesn’t take long at all.
Yes. I pull the sheets and blankets back from the foot of the bed and look for any signs.
Nah!  They’re hiding anyway!! Waiting for the succulent legs
I only check if a hotel feels like maybe it wasn't the best choice. Never actually found any.
Yes. I have glue traps and pocket heat things that I put by the headboard or mattress near the head board.

I do. When I first get into a room, my bags and everything go straight into the bathroom. I put them in the tub or the shower. I get out my flashlight, it has a regular light and a UV setting. They glow under UV light. I check the bed, strip the sheets and lift the mattress, check the headboard and all around the room.

I also make sure that my bags never touch any fabric or carpet in the room. I bring hooks with me and either hang them in the closet or hang them over the top of a door. If I need to get something out of them, they go on the counter in the bathroom or on a desk top. I keep my shoes in the bathroom as well, either on the back of the toilet or on a shelf for counter.

Bedbugs are also attracted to dirty clothes so I have a separate laundry bag that I hang up in the bathroom and all my dirty clothes go in there. Before I pack them back in my bag, I put them in one of those Ziploc rollable vacuum bags, vacuum pack them , and then put them in my bag.

When I get home, my bags go in the guest bathtub along with my shoes. I strip out of my clothing and toss my clothes and the clothes out of my bag directly in the washing machine. I take a shower and put clean clothes on from my house. 

I'll usually leave my bags in the tub for a couple days just to see if I see anything crawling out of them

I had a neighbor who got bedbugs and it cost them like $15,000 out of pocket to get them treated.
Yes
You should definitely check and hopefully there’s nothing going on. But if you see little tiny bugs that are dark rust color that’s a problem.

I never used to.  I went on a trip with my cousin who travels constantly.  Every place we stayed he had us leave our luggage outside while he lifted sheets and mattresses with a flashlight in his hand.  After hearing his story and reading some here I do the same now.  I’ve never seen a bedbug in person and hope it stays that way!
Every time, even if it’s just lifting the sheets checking for blood stains.
Nope.
Never checked, never had issues.
Always always always
Yes, always, and before unpacking.
Whenever I remember to yes. Had bedbugs in college…hell. Never again.

I always do. We stayed in a place earlier this year in Ohio that had them. We did Check the bed and didn’t see anything suspicious but we were covered in bites. We ended up moving rooms after the second night and taking everything to a laundromat and cooking out clothes in the dryer. We kept our bags outside in black trash bags in the sun for a month. Luckily we did not infest our home.

Check. Used to travel a lot for work and found them more than once. The hotel moved me immediately and helped me check the new room (get a different floor on the other side of the building if possible). It takes a minute but totally worth not bringing bedbugs home.

Yessss- I lift the sheets and look at the mattress. Like everyone else has said the reason to be so diligent about avoiding them is the huge expense and hassle of getting rid of them. 

I worked at a hotel (Rodeway Inn, Bozeman, Montana) for a semester in college and there was one room that had bed bugs. The hotel knew about it and even they couldn’t get rid of the bugs. We were told to never rent that room out… except for when the hotel was full. So yeah definitely good to always check- they’re out there

I check online, search reviews on Google and Booking, and keep my carryon/knapsack on the luggage rack. I occasionally do a bed check if the room feels less than pristine. 

I’ve only been bitten once, in a particularly downmarket Motel 8 or Super 6 (last room in town, as we didn’t know there was a Judas Priest concert in Bangor ME that night, and really didn’t think everything would be sold out in Maine in April …). As soon as I got home the suitcase went into a large contractor’s bag in the chest freezer, the clothes went through the washer twice, and then hung in the sun for several days. I escaped any house contamination, thank god.

Let me tell you, I had bedbugs once in my apartment due to them coming through the wall between me and my neighbor. They crawled through the wall outlets. Most stressful and traumatizing 6 months of my life.

These days I check every time I travel. I’ve yet to find any, but did have a false alarm in NYC. Thought I found some droppings so I requested a room change and they upgraded us to a full bedroom suite that would’ve cost double. They emailed me later and said it had been examined and cleared by the exterminator. But yeah I’m not taking any chances.

Yes I do now after getting horrible bed bug bites in a moderately priced hotel! I had such a horrible reaction to them, it took two urgent care trips and two rounds of steroids to get rid of the reaction. I had them all over my face, arms and legs. Each of the bites swelled up to nickel sized welts. I also had to treat every crevice of my home and furniture as I feared i had transported them home in my luggage. I now check meticulously at every hotel and air bnb.
I take my chances at 4/5 star hotels only.  I also never had bed bug issue since college.  Maybe I am lucky in this regard.  I do travel about 100 days a year.
Every time, even if I've stayed there before.
Immediately
Yes
I didn’t use to up until recently, when I got bit by an ant. Lesson learned and from now on I know to check every time
I only encountered bedbugs once in my life. I speak as someone who travels all the time.
Always. Every time.
Every. Single. Time. All four corners of the mattress, and all soft chairs/furniture.

Yes, sounds like you’ve lucked out so far, but I check every time. Just glance around, and go back down to the front desk to request a new room if you see them, it just takes a few minutes more and can alleviate an expensive and time-consuming hassle.

I check everywhere i stay, although I'm sure I'm not that good, and I am always petrified to find anything. I'm not sure what you mean by iron, i just use my eyes and a flashlight. Fortunately I've never seen any bug issues (i've seen other things, but tried to put that out of my head) so I've been happy about that.
Every single time
Every time and I keep my suitcase on the outside the door or I pick them up and put them on top of the table until we make sure everything is good

I don’t check, and I travel about that much for work too.

Maybe I’m flippant about this. I’ve only had bedbugs as an actual issue once — at a Ramada Inn in west Memphis, Arkansas 🥲

Yes! My grandmas house had them. (We think  they hitched a ride after she was in a nursing home rehab). It took multiple heat treatments and chemicals to get rid of those fuckers. My mom was her caretaker at the time…they ended up spreading to her house too!  So yes!!! Always check and wash everything when you get home immediately. I even leave my suitcase in the garage for a whole
Afterwards.
I always look but perhaps not too thoroughly and my eyesight isn’t what it used to be.  Doubt I’d find tiny ones and maybe not spots, but def a big infestation.
I usually don't check but I think I should start.

One of my coworkers checked into a room with bed bugs from a very reputable hotel. I’ve been checking my rooms ever since.  Even after I check I don’t lay anything on the ground or the bed. I only unpack what I need for the day and my luggage stays shut the rest of the time.
No

Yes, I always check. We brought them home from a hotel once and had to pay for an exterminator. We caught it early, and it was still thousands of dollars to get rid of them. I always check now. When I get home, all clothes in the suitcase go in the dryer for 60 mins to kill anything we might have brought home- advice from the exterminator.
It's the first thing I do when I get to my room. I've never gotten any before but it doesn't hurt to check to make sure you don't bring any home.
100% I do! The nightmare of bedbugs is something I don’t want to ever go through.

I had them twice in a hotel room, but I only noticed once I already checked out. I stayed at a different hotel the night after and started feeling itchy. Reached out to both hotels. The hotel I was currently staying did the right thing and checked everything and even sent me a pest control report which was negative. The first hotel was trying to lie to me and after back and forth turned out they had an incident in that room a week prior.

Thankfully I did not bring them home as I was taking all the right steps. Here is what I do since this happened:

I usually don’t check the mattress (they can also hide in the frame or any other small cracks. I pay close attention to the sheets. I never throw or put clothes on the bed. I travel with a hardshell suitcase I always close after use and I always store it at the luggage rack or the bathtub.
YES. Lift the corners, even the mattress cover. Look for blood spots and scurrying bugs. If I have alcohol with me I spray it as it makes them scatter.
I wouldn’t know if I saw one. All the energy spent worrying about it would probably ruin my stay, so no.
Holy @&$!, yes I check! And I briefly search hotel reviews from recent guests - I type in “bedbug” or “bites” in reviews on google or whatever before I book.

I do in poorly maintained (funky-smelling) hotels, rental houses, and in tropical countries. Just a peek under the sheets for the brown spots. I usually don’t bother at a Hilton or Marriott etc in the U.S.
Only if something else about the hotel has raised a big red flag, otherwise I’m not in the mood/financial bracket to keep booking new hotel rooms

Traveling full time , and yes, beds are checked. One thing to be very careful with is never to put your suitcase, backpack, or clothes on the bed; keep it as far away from the bed on a desk or chair with no cushion . If something has touched the bed, it shouldn’t go back in your suitcase or backpack to avoid bringing back unwanted little friends.
I always check and I have run into them and left the hotel.
Yep. Every time. Every where
Every bed, every time!
Always!!!
always
It's the first thing my husband does when we get to a hotel or Airbnb.
Every time. I also leave all of my items except for toiletries in my own suitcase. I don't unpack anything because it's a waste since I'm just going to have to repack it again anyway.
No!
Always.
I always do

Not using the dresser/storage provided other than the closet can help reduce your risk of getting bedbugs quite a bit.

I've started hanging my clothes and keeping other items in my suitcase.
The second I get home I “cook” my bags
Every single time
Always
Yes

💯 always 
I actually don’t bring my luggage up till I’ve properly checked the room,  once im satisfied I’ll go down and let them know if anything is missing or want to change the room or it’s perfect. It gives me peace of mind and staff are aware that I’m not going to let unhygienic stuff slide.  
I always tip the cleaning staff each morning and a smiley note that’s says Thank you : ) 
It’s worked so far!  🤞
Every time. I lift a corner of the sheet at the head of the bed and look at the mattress using the flashlight on my phone. And check around the headboard.

Yes. 100% of the time. 

I peel back all of the sheets down the bare mattress on two corners of each bed.  I inspect the seams and lift the mattress to look between it and the box spring.  I then look over any chairs or sofas as well as open all of the drawers.   I use a flashlight to look behind the headboard (if possible) and any furniture.

Hell yeah! It is our responsibility to not spread them.

I usually book a heat treatment for my luggage upon arrival back home. I drive there directly from the airport and leave all my belongings to be heated.
This gives me such a peace of mind.
I have delt with the scourge before! I don't do a check, but I am on guard. BB have a very distinctive smell, so if I start getting itchy, or notice black spots, I go on the hunt for them!
After staying in an Air BnB that had bedbugs, I will be checking every hotel/Air BnB I stay in going forward
Life is too short for that

Don’t forget to check other places too! 

My friend went to a hotel and did the bed check and thought she was good to go. There were bed bugs in the couch.
We encountered them on a trip about 10 years ago.  So we do check.  A short review of the bedding is usually enough.

My wife checks everywhere

I used to think it was excessive, then we got em in our apartment complex by someone’s wash not being thoroughly cleaned with hot water

Now I don’t blame her

Every time.  Peel back the covers and check the “piping” on the mattress, this is where you would usually find them.  If you find them, leave the room asap and don’t stay in the hotel.  Had coworkers who had to spend thousands to eradicate them after they hitched a ride back home in luggage.  

I would also recommend avoid any teapot or coffee pot in room, they tend to skip cleaning these thoroughly, and I’ve seen things growing in them occasionally.  Be wary of any glassware in room as many hotels have been known to cut corners, ie windex and a rag to “clean” a glass before returning it to the minibar.
Yes every time

Yes, I absolutely do. I stayed at a place in Sacramento once before and woke up the next morning with bedbug bites all down my neck and I had a rash for weeks after, it was horrible.

Ever since, I always check my room everywhere I stay.
I used to not until a hotel I stayed at had a bedbug scare. I didn’t get them, but it freaked me out so bad.

They lives everywhere. I had them a few years ago. Nearly drove me mad. I had to ove, and leave all my furniture behind. All of it. Bed is a euphemism. They can live in your coffee table. They live in your baseboards. They infest your electrical outlets. They're awful. One of the most horrifying experiences of my life, and I've had some bad experiences.

Traveling in Morocco, I opened a paperback book I'd left on the nightstand in a nice hotel to find several crawling inside the pages. I quickly squashed them. I presumed I'd carried them from the last hotel, which was kind of seedy. 
When I returned home to the US, it was below freezing and I left my luggage with all its contents outside in my yard for several days, then washed everything in hot water. But then the psychological torture started.
Every night I'd feel things crawling on me - would sit up and turn on the lights and find nothing. I'd find a tiny itchy spot on my skin and the anxiety would escalate. I was obsessively checking all my furniture and clothing, and couldn't stop reading bedbug horror stories online. 
It took several months to feel normal again and sleep through the night without that crawly feeling.
I'm not sure my mental health could survive an actual infestation and I always check hotel rooms - around the mattress, cracks and crevices of any furniture and behind the headboard if possible. Luggage up off the floor and bed. And I wash all clothes in hot water the minute I get home.

100-150 days travelling yearly for past 10 years (excluding covid years). 

I only checked maybe 5 times altogether when the room or bed looked shady. 

Got bit by bedbugs twice, not nice but far worse thing happened to me so far. I'm definitely too lazy to waste time checking the room every time I move, usually I'm happy just to finally relax when I check in. 

The two times were where I wouldn't expect it really, first one was a hostel in my own country's capital in Europe (needed a quick crash after a work party) and second one way a very nice hotel in Vietnam I had stayed before a few times without any issues. 

I'm surprised how many people say they put their bag in a bathtub etc.
Give a quick check and thats it!
EVERY...SINGLE...TIME...    Bags don't cone in the room until I check.

Every time. A quick inspection could prevent any unwanted passengers from coming back with you. You should take other preventative measures such as storing your bags somewhere where they are unlikely to come into contact with any bugs. I also put my bags in the bathtub overnight when I get home. If there are any in there they will try to get out but will get stuck in the tub. They cannot climb porcelain.
Absolutely!
No but I should

Never checked. Never had an issue (knocks on wood). I'm not even sure what I'll do if I checked and found them since my hotel booking is usually done by a 3rd party for work. They usually book really great and upscale hotels, though.
I always check the crevices of the mattress, and I keep my backpack as far away from the bed and other furniture as possible, usually on the bathroom counter or hanging from a towel hook.
If you ever hear someone who works at the front desk say “ baseballs or blueberries” that is industry code for bed bugs. I traveled 100-120 days a year for 20 years.

Yes every single hotel. I didn't used to until I was sharing one with my sister and she had one crawl on her. Now I check every hotel. Usually I'll ask the front desk if I can checkout the room before checking in. Most places don't give you a hard time about it but I almost never reserve rooms online
Yes, yes, 1000% yes. If I found out I afterwards that I had stayed in an infested room I would trash all my clothes and luggage as well.
Holy hell-brought bb back from the Williamsburg lodge. My son still has trauma from it. We had to heat treat our entire house just so he would sleep in his room again. Please check your hotel room.
Never thought too. I travel a lot for work too but only stay in 5 star hotels where i would expect the beds to be changed every couple days.
Absolutely not. My kids are jumping on the beds with their shoes on before I can even put down my purse. Who has time for that???

i’m gonna be so real i’ve spent around a year total traveling around the country often staying in the cheapest motel or literal first motel i saw. i’ve hooked up with strangers. i’ve never encountered bedbugs. like maybe i just got lucky but it doesn’t seem like they’re all that common?

when i worked at a hotel i had a few guests complain of bedbugs & upon investigation there were no bedbugs & the guests’ “injuries” always looked like either a very mild rash or absolutely nothing - likely a reaction to dramatic change in weather or the bleach we used to clean the sheets.

Yes I do...and dryer sheets in everything..(hopefully it works?). 

There may be some essential oils as well that may be preventative until you check out .

But II check it all the time before I touch quite a few things even at the nicest hotels
What happens if you find them? Is changing rooms in a hotel enough? Or do you switch properties? What if you have no choice?
Does a mattress encasement make you feel better? Do you look inside of it?
Where do you look exactly?

How likely are you to find them? My father's house who had them quite bad was treated, I tried seeing any proof leftover, but found nothing. I searched the whole mattress and box spring. But my husband and I still woke up with bites and woke up in the night to find them in the bed.
If you do find bedbugs when you leave, what precautions would you take to avoid bringing them home?
I have read that they can easily climb the luggage rack so I put things in bathtub until I have cleared the room.
Also I never leave my luggage open when I leave the room - always close it with a zip just in case

In addition, might want to carry some [Diatomaceous Earth (DE)](https://mandmpestcontrol.com/how-to-use-diatomaceous-earth-to-kill-bed-bugs/) to surround the hard surface luggage is set on; if concerned, do not place sleeping clothes back on suitcase (nullifies precautions taken), or place them on sealed (saturated with DE powder) bag, to hot wash later.
Last time I checked I found a double headed dildo and and a used condom.. 🤢

Agreed.  I got bedbugs on the Camino and was so fucking miserable.  We took everything we were carrying and ran it through a HOT washer and HOT HOT dryer (even melted some stuff).  I’ve had a lot of mosquito bites in my life, but the bedbug bites were worse.  I ended up with prescription cream for itching.  Check every place you stay, and for God’s sake don’t take them home!!!
This 100%. I also keep my luggage in the bathroom as they’re less likely to be in there.
I bring tape. If there's major seams along the headboards that I don't trust, I tape them off
Yes and my luggage never goes on the floor either, always the desk or dresser
Happy cake day
Ohhh I never checked the air Bnb.. good call
Hopefully you got a refund
Egads! And doesn't that also show everything else?  Like a sex murder scene, right?
So do sperm stains. Know less, sleep better. I do always check for bed bugs though but not with an UV light 😂
The first time I ever traveled for work, half of us in the group had bedbugs. I've been paranoid ever since, though I thankfully didn't bring them home with me!
Your luck will run out eventually.

> I travel 90 days a year, have for years, and have both never checked and also never had a problem.

Same for me. And I had them several times.

Never in the cheapest hostels - but in the most expensive ones.

Lol.
yes, me in a hotel room bed, realizing I never thought in my life to check for bed bugs. Now I feel like I got 100 bugs on me sucking on my blood help
Was just about to comment this. I swear there's something on my arm, but every time I check... nothing.
How did you get rid of them?
Agree-you don’t have a problem until you do. I was eaten alive 15 years ago and used to travel weekly and have found bed bugs 3 times in the subsequent years (weekly travel).

Same here. The only time I had a bed bug bite was at a very old castle turned B&B in Tuscany, Italy. 
That’s like 1 out of 1000+

I used to travel for work constantly (4 days / week), and I travel globally for fun and stay in low cost options in underdeveloped countries, and I've never had an issue. I'm not saying it's the right way to do it or that I'm not lucky for having avoided bed bugs this whole time. I just think constantly thinking about potential bed bugs is not worth the mental energy of checking everything every time I travel given the low chance of actually getting bed bugs.
Hundreds? Omg that sounds awful
There's a bed bug website?
I also use wipes on all the light switches and the hair dryer. I doubt housekeeping cleans those.
I just put the remote in a ziplock bag and keep it in there.
How does that work? (Checking a bed with an iron)
I would have stayed at the bus station or a public bathroom before staying in that room.

When I went to Cuba there were roaches in the Airbnb, when I got back I pretty much stripped in the driveway, the clothes I was wearing and in my suitcase went directly in the washer just to be sure nothing that might have hitched a ride was still living.

>more than likely the same person that cleaned your room cleaned the one they want to move you to.

If you mean the cleaner was sloppy and that's why there are bed bugs, that's not how it works, it has very little to do with cleaning. If you mean the cleaner will spread the infestation to other rooms, maybe they eventually will, but not that fast.

They are less common than you'd think from all the noise so it's not crazy to choose to take the risk though. Personally, I do check, it takes a minute per stay.

My spouse worked at a very high-end hotel, and it was quite alarming how often they'd have to eradicate bedbugs. At least 3 or 4 times a year. I am happy to say they never tried to treat and reuse the mattresses. They were immediately disposed of.
Wait - could you explain this a little more? Do you put the glue traps on top of the heat things?
I need more info this!

Honest question, do you feel like this takes away from your travel experience to feel like you’re living out of a bathroom or quarantining the room before it’s cleared? 

In my head, the allure of hotels is to have all the convenience you would have in your house like organization or comfy bedding/seating. I feel in the middle because I generally don’t unpack for my stay and wouldn’t be too inconvenienced by your way, but I do think it’s odd that some people really enjoy putting their clothes into the hotel dresser.
Holy crap, how long did it take to get rid of them if you know?
May I ask where in Ohio this was? Traveling there soon
How did you get rid of the bedbugs in your apartment?
I read the reviews and comments on trip advisor, hotels.com to make sure there hasn’t been a single mention of bedbugs or I don’t book it.
Me too!!!!!
You should. Absolutely. I know of hotels even higher rated than those you've mentioned  who have to deal with bedbugs at least 2 or 3 times a year.
Where do you take your luggage to be heat treated?
Change hotels immediately.   Back down to the front desk, get a refund, and get the hell out of there.
Burn the hotel down
Yes. But you be damn sure to check the new room. I always look when I travel. 26 years in pest control and I've got horror stories.
Happy cake day
